articles.headline: America Stares Down a Trump-Biden Repeat in Disbelief and Denial
articles.snippet: Unable to fathom a 2020 rematch, many Americans are clinging to forlorn hopes and floating wild theories — including that Michelle Obama might replace President Biden.
articles.abstract: Unable to fathom a 2020 rematch, many Americans are clinging to forlorn hopes and floating wild theories — including that Michelle Obama might replace President Biden.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is cruising to the Democratic nomination. Former President Donald J. Trump could begin to wrap up his party’s nod within days.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: Sports Illustrated Thrown Into Chaos With Mass Layoffs
articles.snippet: The announcement on Friday left in doubt what lies ahead for the venerable publication, with some staff members dismissed immediately and others told they would keep their jobs for at least 90 days.
articles.abstract: The announcement on Friday left in doubt what lies ahead for the venerable publication, with some staff members dismissed immediately and others told they would keep their jobs for at least 90 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sports Illustrated, the venerable bible of sports journalism, has been in decline for years, as the internet annihilated print magazines and cost-cutting turned the weekly publication into a monthly and whittled its staff. But on Friday, the magazine received perhaps its toughest blow yet.
articles.byline: By Kevin Draper and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: Stocks Climb to Record, Lifted by Big Tech and Rate Cut Hopes
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 crossed above its January 2022 peak after weeks of wavering. Investors have been buying stocks after homing in on signals that the Fed’s campaign of raising interest rates is over.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 crossed above its January 2022 peak after weeks of wavering. Investors have been buying stocks after homing in on signals that the Fed’s campaign of raising interest rates is over.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market broke through to new heights on Friday, with the S&P 500 index finally hitting a record after weeks of bumping up against its previous peak.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and J. Edward Moreno

articles.headline: Stocks Are in a Bull Market. What Does That Mean?
articles.snippet: It doesn’t mean stocks will continue to rise indefinitely, but it does reflect a generally optimistic outlook on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: It doesn’t mean stocks will continue to rise indefinitely, but it does reflect a generally optimistic outlook on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: The S&P 500 index closed at a record on Friday, crossing above its old high-water mark, set in early 2022. The gains show that investors have overcome fears of rising interest rates and panic about a recession that had governed stock trading for much of the past two years.
articles.byline: By J. Edward Moreno

articles.headline: Divisions Emerging in Israel Over Gaza War
articles.snippet: Protesters demanded action to free hostages, a war cabinet minister criticized the military campaign and the Israeli prime minister publicly ruled out a two-state solution, rebuffing the U.S.
articles.abstract: Protesters demanded action to free hostages, a war cabinet minister criticized the military campaign and the Israeli prime minister publicly ruled out a two-state solution, rebuffing the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: After nearly 15 weeks of war, sharp divisions within Israel over the path forward in the Gaza Strip are increasingly coming into the open.
articles.byline: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Aaron Boxerman, Anushka Patil and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: The U.S. Seems to Be Dodging a Recession. What Could Go Wrong?
articles.snippet: Economists have become increasingly optimistic about the odds of a soft landing. But as 2024 begins to unfold, risks remain.
articles.abstract: Economists have become increasingly optimistic about the odds of a soft landing. But as 2024 begins to unfold, risks remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: With inflation falling, unemployment low and the Federal Reserve signaling it could soon begin cutting interest rates, forecasters are becoming increasingly optimistic that the U.S. economy could avoid a recession.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Congratulations, You’re the Oldest Person in Town! Please Accept This Cane.
articles.snippet: For over a century, towns in New England have presented their oldest residents with ceremonial canes. In some places, the honor endures — for those willing to accept it, that is.
articles.abstract: For over a century, towns in New England have presented their oldest residents with ceremonial canes. In some places, the honor endures — for those willing to accept it, that is.
articles.byline: By Jenna Russell and Sophie Park

articles.headline: For the Anti-Trump Wing of the G.O.P., It All Comes Down to Tuesday
articles.snippet: The old guard of the Republican Party has rallied around Nikki Haley ahead of New Hampshire’s primary, in a long-shot bid to stop the former president’s march to the nomination.
articles.abstract: The old guard of the Republican Party has rallied around Nikki Haley ahead of New Hampshire’s primary, in a long-shot bid to stop the former president’s march to the nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first-in-the-nation primary could be the last stand for the anti-Trump Republican.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Michael C. Bender and Jazmine Ulloa

articles.headline: In Strategic Bind, Israel Weighs Freeing Hostages Against Destroying Hamas
articles.snippet: Some Israeli commanders said the government’s two main goals were mutually incompatible. To eradicate Hamas, the military would have to engage in a lengthy war that would most likely cost the hostages’ lives.
articles.abstract: Some Israeli commanders said the government’s two main goals were mutually incompatible. To eradicate Hamas, the military would have to engage in a lengthy war that would most likely cost the hostages’ lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than 100 days of war, Israel’s limited progress in dismantling Hamas has raised doubts within the military’s high command about the near-term feasibility of achieving the country’s principal wartime objectives: eradicating Hamas and also liberating the Israeli hostages still in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: As Missiles Strike, a Radio Station Broadcasts the Rage of a Battered City
articles.snippet: Kharkiv, in northern Ukraine, is under almost daily bombardment. Radio Boiling Over serves as a megaphone for residents’ fears and frustrations.
articles.abstract: Kharkiv, in northern Ukraine, is under almost daily bombardment. Radio Boiling Over serves as a megaphone for residents’ fears and frustrations.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the middle of the night in early January when a Russian missile streaked in and exploded in the center of Kharkiv, blasting down walls and shattering windows.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: The Baltimore Sun’s New Owner Has the Newsroom on Edge
articles.snippet: The news that David D. Smith, the executive chairman of the conservative Sinclair Broadcast Group, had bought The Sun has generated alarm inside and outside the newsroom.
articles.abstract: The news that David D. Smith, the executive chairman of the conservative Sinclair Broadcast Group, had bought The Sun has generated alarm inside and outside the newsroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, desperate to avoid being acquired by a hedge fund, staff members of The Baltimore Sun made public pleas for a local entrepreneur to buy their publication.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson

articles.headline: How Allegations of an Office Romance Came to Complicate the Case Against Trump
articles.snippet: The claims involving Fani Willis and Nathan Wade, the special prosecutor she hired to manage the sprawling case in Georgia, have led to new questions about Mr. Wade’s qualifications.
articles.abstract: The claims involving Fani Willis and Nathan Wade, the special prosecutor she hired to manage the sprawling case in Georgia, have led to new questions about Mr. Wade’s qualifications.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fani T. Willis ran for district attorney in Georgia’s Fulton County in 2020 with the slogan “Integrity matters!” and frequently pummeled the incumbent, her former boss, with accusations of ethical lapses. Soon after her victory, she set up a group to interview job candidates called the Integrity Transition Hiring Committee.
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: ‘America Is Under Attack’: Inside the Anti-D.E.I. Crusade
articles.snippet: The backlash against “wokeism” has led a growing number of states to ban D.E.I. programs at public universities. Thousands of emails and other documents reveal the playbook — and grievances — behind one strand of the anti-D.E.I. campaign.
articles.abstract: The backlash against “wokeism” has led a growing number of states to ban D.E.I. programs at public universities. Thousands of emails and other documents reveal the playbook — and grievances — behind one strand of the anti-D.E.I. campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: The backlash against “wokeism” has led a growing number of states to ban D.E.I. programs at public universities. Thousands of emails and other documents reveal the playbook — and grievances — behind one strand of the anti-D.E.I. campaign.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: As Switzerland’s Glaciers Shrink, a Way of Life May Melt Away
articles.snippet: Rising temperatures and retreating glaciers threaten Europe’s water tower, forcing local farmers to adapt and presaging larger troubles downstream.
articles.abstract: Rising temperatures and retreating glaciers threaten Europe’s water tower, forcing local farmers to adapt and presaging larger troubles downstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: For centuries, Swiss farmers have sent their cattle, goats and sheep up the mountains to graze in warmer months before bringing them back down at the start of autumn. Devised in the Middle Ages to save precious grass in the valleys for winter stock, the tradition of “summering” has so transformed the countryside into a patchwork of forests and pastures that maintaining its appearance was written into the Swiss Constitution as an essential role of agriculture.
articles.byline: By George Steinmetz and Catherine Porter

articles.headline: An Atheist Chaplain and a Death Row Inmate’s Final Hours
articles.snippet: Devin Moss spent a year ministering to convicted killer Phillip Hancock. Together, they wrestled with one question: How to face death without God.
articles.abstract: Devin Moss spent a year ministering to convicted killer Phillip Hancock. Together, they wrestled with one question: How to face death without God.
articles.lead_paragraph: “God, that chicken.” Devin Moss has a voice that rumbles, low and slow like distant thunder, but this morning it was softer, more contemplative. His hands gripped the steering wheel of his rental car. He was dressed head to toe in white linen, his body glowing in an almost celestial way, as he drove toward the Oklahoma State Penitentiary.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg and Desiree Rios

articles.headline: How Nikki Haley’s Lean Years Led Her Into an Ethical Thicket
articles.snippet: From her earliest days in South Carolina politics, Ms. Haley’s public service paid personal financial dividends.
articles.abstract: From her earliest days in South Carolina politics, Ms. Haley’s public service paid personal financial dividends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley had been serving in the South Carolina legislature for less than two years when she applied for a job in late 2006 as an accounting clerk at Wilbur Smith Associates, an engineering and design firm with state contracts.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Alexandra Berzon

articles.headline: Where Textile Mills Thrived, Remnants Battle for Survival
articles.snippet: Apparel makers in the Carolinas say trade policy must change because of a boom in tariff-free shipments to U.S. consumers from foreign manufacturers.
articles.abstract: Apparel makers in the Carolinas say trade policy must change because of a boom in tariff-free shipments to U.S. consumers from foreign manufacturers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his 40-year career, William Lucas has seen nearly every step in the erosion of the American garment industry. As general manager of Eagle Sportswear, a company in Middlesex, N.C., that cuts, sews and assembles apparel, he hopes to keep what’s left of that industry intact.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Audra Melton

articles.headline: Is Kim Jong-un Really Planning an Attack This Time?
articles.snippet: An intensification of nuclear threats from North Korea while the world is preoccupied with other wars has ignited an urgent debate over Mr. Kim’s motives.
articles.abstract: An intensification of nuclear threats from North Korea while the world is preoccupied with other wars has ignited an urgent debate over Mr. Kim’s motives.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Korea fired hundreds of artillery shells in waters near South Korean border islands on Jan. 5. Last week, it said it no longer regarded the South as inhabited by “fellow countrymen” but as a “hostile state” it would subjugate through a nuclear war. On Friday, it said it had tested an underwater nuclear drone to help repel U.S. Navy fleets.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: War Has Already Hurt the Economies of Israel’s Nearest Neighbors
articles.snippet: The impact on global growth of the Middle East violence has so far been contained. That’s not the case for Egypt, Lebanon and Jordan, which were already struggling.
articles.abstract: The impact on global growth of the Middle East violence has so far been contained. That’s not the case for Egypt, Lebanon and Jordan, which were already struggling.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the Red Sea, attacks by Iranian-backed Houthi militants on commercial ships continue to disrupt a crucial trade route and raise shipping costs. The threat of escalation there and around flash points in Lebanon, Iraq, Syria, Yemen and now Iran and Pakistan ratchets up every day.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Deep Under Gaza, Evidence of Cells and Hostages, Israel Says
articles.snippet: The Israeli military took reporters on a tour of an underground compound in the Gazan city of Khan Younis, where it says about 20 hostages were held by Hamas.
articles.abstract: The Israeli military took reporters on a tour of an underground compound in the Gazan city of Khan Younis, where it says about 20 hostages were held by Hamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a subterranean compound deep below Khan Younis, a Hamas stronghold in the southern Gaza Strip, the five cells with barred doors that the Israeli military says held hostages abducted from Israel had clearly been constructed long in advance.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Ron DeSantis Ends Campaign for President
articles.snippet: The Florida governor, who once appeared to be Donald Trump’s most daunting challenger, ran a costly, turbulent campaign that failed to catch on with Republican voters.
articles.abstract: The Florida governor, who once appeared to be Donald Trump’s most daunting challenger, ran a costly, turbulent campaign that failed to catch on with Republican voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida suspended his campaign for president on Sunday and endorsed former President Donald J. Trump, marking a spectacular implosion for a candidate once seen as having the best chance to dethrone Mr. Trump as the Republican Party’s nominee in 2024.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Nehamas, Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Modi Opens a Giant Temple in a Triumph for India’s Hindu Nationalists
articles.snippet: The temple inaugurated by the prime minister is on the disputed site of a centuries-old mosque destroyed in a Hindu mob attack that set a precedent of impunity in cases of violence against Muslims.
articles.abstract: The temple inaugurated by the prime minister is on the disputed site of a centuries-old mosque destroyed in a Hindu mob attack that set a precedent of impunity in cases of violence against Muslims.
articles.lead_paragraph: They fanned out across the vast country, knocking on doors in the name of a cause that would redefine India.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Atul Loke

articles.headline: These Seven Tech Stocks Are Driving the Market
articles.snippet: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
articles.abstract: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
articles.lead_paragraph: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
articles.byline: By Karl Russell and Joe Rennison

articles.headline: How a Diversity Initiative Changed Course With the Times
articles.snippet: Amid a fresh backlash against D.E.I. efforts, OneTen met resistance as a program for Black workers only. It has shifted its emphasis to “equity for all” and a more hands-on approach.
articles.abstract: Amid a fresh backlash against D.E.I. efforts, OneTen met resistance as a program for Black workers only. It has shifted its emphasis to “equity for all” and a more hands-on approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, dozens of big companies formed a coalition and declared an ambitious goal: to lift one million Black workers into good-paying jobs over the next 10 years, by hiring or promoting them.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Facing Backlash, Some Corporate Leaders Go ‘Under the Radar’ With D.E.I.
articles.snippet: New hurdles and opposition to diversity programs have pushed some business leaders to approach their D.E.I. initiatives “in a less in your face way,” while others are doubling down.
articles.abstract: New hurdles and opposition to diversity programs have pushed some business leaders to approach their D.E.I. initiatives “in a less in your face way,” while others are doubling down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past two years, as Ishan Bhabha and his colleagues at the law firm Jenner & Block prepared briefs for the affirmative action case the Supreme Court ruled on last year, Mr. Bhabha had a realization: If higher education institutions like Harvard were the first target of litigation about diversity, equity and inclusion, America’s corporate boardrooms were probably next.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg

articles.headline: Russian Celebrities Caught ‘Almost Naked’ Are Now Dressing to Appease
articles.snippet: President Vladimir Putin derided those “jumping around without pants,” at a party, while some guests have tried to make amends through donations and adopting a cat.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir Putin derided those “jumping around without pants,” at a party, while some guests have tried to make amends through donations and adopting a cat.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian pop star winced as the black kitten he was cuddling in Russian-occupied Ukraine licked the crook of his neck for about the 15th time.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne

articles.headline: Haley Gets a Trump Matchup, but Now Faces the Trump Machine
articles.snippet: As Nikki Haley celebrated Ron DeSantis’s departure from the Republican primary, Donald J. Trump turned his firepower toward his final rival.
articles.abstract: As Nikki Haley celebrated Ron DeSantis’s departure from the Republican primary, Donald J. Trump turned his firepower toward his final rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: With only about 48 hours left to campaign in the New Hampshire primary, Nikki Haley finally got the two-person race she wanted.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Jazmine Ulloa and Michael C. Bender

articles.headline: Americans Feel Better About the Economy. Will That Help Biden?
articles.snippet: The White House is embracing a nascent uptick in economic sentiment. It is likely good news — but how it will map to votes is complicated.
articles.abstract: The White House is embracing a nascent uptick in economic sentiment. It is likely good news — but how it will map to votes is complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Low approval ratings and rock-bottom consumer confidence figures have dogged President Biden for months now, a worrying sign for the White House as the country enters a presidential election year. But recent data suggests the tide is beginning to turn.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek
